job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great place to work for anyone.
cons: I can not think of any negatives

review_title: Progress at the cost of quality
job_title: Program Coordinator in Kansas City, KS
pros: Provides wide range of services, it is in many ways, a one stop shop. There are great people who work there and community is vibrant and diverse. This agency is currently WyCo's best hope for mental health. There are good things happening here and it's a good place to get your feet wet.
cons: This agency does value staff. There are high rates of turnover and burnout. They are not fully accountable to the community they serve. WBHN is not operating in alignment with their mission. Leadership is hollow and lacks follow through.

review_title: Co workers are great, pay is unlivable
job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros:
Great teammates, if this is truly your calling this is a great place to work on the adult side. 
The clients were my favorite though. And peers you work with all are motivated to go to truly help people. Unlike other fields, here everyone's focus is on how to help the clients, the obstacles thrown their way and help them succeed.
cons: But hopefully you have a trust fund because it is also unliveable to live off of 33k a year. After 6 years and having to work additional jobs to make ends meet I finally had to leave because evergreen pre pandemic we almost never got a raise. They could never afford to give us one. And honestly with as much as we ran out cars into the ground, flat tires, and oil changes not to mention they pay less than federal standards for miles in gas compensation.... it just gets overwhelming.

review_title: Helping Others May Make You Unable To Help Yourself
job_title: Adult Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Opportunity to serve the undeserved in your community, Salary is steadily increasing (got hired on around 35k a year, steadily increasing toward 50k)
cons: Too much office politics, you pretty much an Uber Driver (number one client need is typically transportation), Management does not have your back

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Good benefits, 3 weeks paid vacation and 12 days paid sick leave per year. Great coworkers and work atmosphere.
cons: Upper management is very out of touch with the needs of the employees. Often undercuts salaries of existing employees despite offering higher salaries to new hires. No upward mobility.

review_title: Absolutely awful, traumatized from working there
job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Kansas City, KS
pros: Some benefits. Coworkers were nice. At least I know to avoid places like this in the future.
cons: Management knows nothing about mental health, no supervision provided, therapists are stretched way too thin. I was told they were still “developing” the job role when I was hired. Which ended up meaning they just kept adding responsibilities to my role without extra pay or telling me how I was supposed to find the time to achieve these responsibilities. No direct supervisor the majority of the time I was there because the previous one quit due to burnout, and they couldn’t find a replacement. CEO is well known to not care about clients. Building is super old. Several other therapists quit after I did, and they experienced a therapist walkout in the beginning of 2018. Everyone is disposable to them. Toxic work environment to a tee.

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros:
Flexible schedule 
Great families
New every day
cons:
Physical Safety concerns
Unsafe working conditions

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Flexibility and make your own schedule.
cons: Lots of travel. Must enter crowded places often. Emotionally draining.

job_title: Attendant Care in Kansas City, KS
pros: Offers experience in mental/behavioral health work
cons: Unorganized, not all employees are qualified, some some employees lack passion to fully serve their clients, underpaid

job_title: Mental Health Therapist in Kansas City, KS
pros:
Ok pay
Vacation time
Health insurance 
Nice coworkers but underappreciated
cons:
Says Trauma informed but really knows nothing about it and doesn't model it or implement it(I was screamed at for leaving while sick after the fact, my coworkers understood the day of but my boss wanted to guilt me only after getting my 2 weeks notice?)
No communication 
No middle management due to constant turnover 
Senior directors smile but they are scary af beware 
Your job duties will constantly change
Processes at work constantly change 
There are no hard and sound "policies"; it's whatever the senior director thinks because she's a control freak 
All of the senior directors are basically hanging on by a string and that is the atmosphere on the third floor if you are a therapist: get ready for positive juju (sarcasm!)

review_title: Good people to work for and with.
job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: The best thing about WC is the people that you work for and with. If you are in direct client services it can be VERY demanding and draining work but if you have good people on your Team who you can talk to and get support from, it makes a world of difference. It can also be very rewarding work b/c you are helping people who have tremendous needs with multiple issues, not just mental illness. Grinding poverty and lack of access to good health care lead to making mental health recovery even more challenging. If you can keep a good perspective on things and take care of yourself - including support from other workers - you will find that it can be "the hardest job you'll ever love."
cons: See the "Pros" for the main ones, like working w/ people in poverty and dealing w/ people w/ addictions and major health problems. Also, since funding comes mainly from Medicaid, the documentation and paperwork - even though quite necessary - can become a huge stone around your neck. One has to learn how to balance work and home life and sometimes the job itself makes that very difficult.

job_title: Adult Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: If you are passionate about helping the most vulnerable members of society, you can do a lot of good direct work here. A lot of support from peers. The PTO they offer is better than most. Can be rewarding in a non monetary way.
cons: Middle management and upper management say they care about employees and employee developmemt, but it doesn't feel that way. Extremely high job expectations with high stress levels at extremely low pay. Unsafe job with little to no support from management. Little to no opportunity for advancement or training. Benefits are bad except for the PTO and holiday pay. They try to be "trauma informed" but don't really make the grade when it comes to caring for employees.

job_title: Customer Care Representative in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great PTO, sick time, coworkers are great, benefits were great other than the expensive health insurance
cons: The doctors there don't care at all about the front desk staff. Always calling in for no reason, cancelling appointments, making the front desk the person the patients cuss and get frustrated at. The doctors belittle the front desk staff. The supervisors don't care about the employees at all. There is ALWAYS lay offs, making everyone fearful that they may be next to lose their jobs.

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: My supportive co workers who are always there to help. The families and kiddos I had the opportunity to spend time with and have built relationships with. Making a difference and flexible schedules. Was able to work remotely.
cons: My supervisor. Lack of support to accomplish anything. Supervisions should help someone understand what they need to work on.. Not have you leaving more confused than before you got there. Consistency. Communication on ALL levels and never once appreciated. As a young professional in the field of social work this company has literally traumatized me in a way that made me lose my ability to trust others.

review_title: Great place to work - It's like working with your best friend every day.
job_title: Case Manager
pros: Family oriented, flexibility in scheduling (in some roles), nice people, great benefits and awesome leaders.  Great coworkers and so much love for what we do to help the community.
cons: Because its a community mental health service provider, you won't get the same salary you might in a private practice. Its more than made up for in the family atmosphere.

review_title: All the long timers have left... that says enough
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, KS
pros: Due to the close knit environment, sometimes it can feel really homey. Most coworkers are nice
cons: No raises( or better yet raises are RARE)- but also due to lack of funding. no opportunities for growth-you’re basically ball and chained to the job you’re hired for and if you want more you’re forced to leave the company. HIGH TURNOVER -coworkers are literally here today gone tomorrow. There used to be flexibility with schedules but they are implementing a Point system soon. Sorry you don’t pay us enough for rules like that.

review_title: Good company to start your career, little to no opportunity for growth in salary or performance-based promotion
job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Overall a good experience for my first employer post-college graduation.  The team leader who I was assigned to was excellent and coached me on a variety of approaches, viewpoints and proactively listened to my struggles and successes being new to working in mental health fresh out of college with a degree in public relations.  Took a chance on getting to know me in the interview (hour-long in person with hiring manager and my soon-to-be team leader or service coordinator per their nomenclature) and saw potential.  Allowed creative approaches to be taken and emphasis on supporting clients in being successful was bountiful among coworkers.  Good supportive environment from immediate supervisors and fellow case managers.
cons:
Low income starting wage for a college graduate with a four-year degree - my co-workers in orientation (both had jobs in professional career unlike me) and I made less than $15/hourly  with no compensation for overtime.  I heard that there was a class action lawsuit after I left in 2014 on employee-overtime pay but I must've missed out on knowing about it or if/how overtime pay was compensated for but it'd be nice if I was still eligible to be a plaintiff in it!!

 Upper management at times had unrealistic expectations, and there was a sense that case managers at times were afraid to voice concerns.  Upper management didn't consult case managers when making changes in expectations or productivity, and often I feel there was little transparency for reason behind changes that affected my work life directly.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, KS
pros: Working with mental health professionals who are dedicated and loyal that truly care and want to help others.
cons:
Most company leaders have forgotten why they are in the field.   New office furniture, travel expenses, proud new owners of new BMW, Lexus, Nissan.etc...

The Headlines Might Have Read:
Two Years After Company Lay-offs and Salary Cuts  Employees Continue to Question Nepotism and Ethics of Company Leaders including BMOC.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Manassas, VA
pros: Great Work Life Balence.  The CEO is not your average CEO.  He truely cares about others and strives to do the right thing.  He is always willing to meet with employees.  Management staff are willing to learn and listen to the employee with an objective ear.
cons: It is a nonprofit Agency, so the pay is challenging.

review_title: Very challenging work, but good people to work with.
job_title: Case Manager in Medellín, Antioquia
pros: Good support from peers and some very good people to serve, especially if you are doing direct client services. It can be very rewarding.
cons: Sometimes not enough time to do the work they want you to do. This can be very stressful for someone who doesn't manage time well.

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: You will gain a lot of experience. If your field is Mental Health this would not be a bad place to start.
cons: Management is very dysfunctional and unorganized and totally unprofessional.  Wyandot Inc. is big organization and this unprofessionalism  is like an infections cancer that will soon cause the company to implode.

review_title: If you want any growth, this isn't where to find it
job_title: Adult Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Benefits are good and getting paid to have little work to do other than taxi driving clients around is good if you dont actually care about having fulfillment in your days or career.
cons: Lack of team atmosphere, 99.8% in your time is in your car being a taxi driver, little assistance from management, no communication between docs/rn's and others who are vital to collaborative care, no engagement requirements of clients so much of your time is spent trying to engage clients who never wanted the service to begin with and aren't required to have it to be in services, hygiene issues and bed bugs, training is unproductive and not useful at all. This job should technically just be called what it is- mental health transportion services. On demand taxi driver to clients who are only being enabled to NOT find recovery and independence.  There is also no opportunity for growth within this company without getting a higher level degree. Treatment isnt the goal... shutting people up by giving them rides all day is all it is. Not case management if youve ever seen case management in mental health elsewhere. Not good work/life balance due to no cell phones (which they are now working on) so having to use your personal phone and having clients call all hours of night and weekend whether you answer or set the boundary or not. Mileage is paid under the minimum for what it should be at 43 cents per mile. No. desk of your own, shared computers and office phones, and ipads given are useless bc you cant see a thing on them.

review_title: Good starter social work job, quick burn out.
job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Great flexibility in work hours since you schedule with all clients on your own. Can be rewarding on good days.
cons: Little guidance or training from management. High stress job with high expectations- often requiring you to work more than 40 hours a week. Low salary, no annual raises.

job_title: Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros:
Create your own work schedule/flexible
Work with children or adults to provide them with services/supports needed
cons:
Salary is low
Stress level/self care

review_title: Hardest Job of My Life With Low Pay
job_title: Youth Mental Health Case Manager in Kansas City, KS
pros: Helping People, Building Relationships with clients and families, Flexible Work Schedule, Some Provided Training.
cons: Not Very Much Training, HIGH CASELOADS, Challenging Populations, Poor Management, Unrealistic Productivity Standards, No Respect For Employees, Continuous Workload

job_title: Part Time in Kansas City, KS
pros: The peers you work with are great! You can learn a lot if you start your social service  career here.
cons: Management ...training material (lack of)...mileage reimbursement...pay..security...paperwork  .

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Kansas City, KS
pros: Flexibility and time off.
cons: Wyandot Center- poor leadership on all levels,  lack of professionalism, no raises or incentives, lack of creativity in how to provide services and work with less.

review_title: Learned a lot, experienced disappointment that my career goals would not be met with the agency.
